questions.question: Statements

answers.option: During an initialization all old tables will be removed
answers.explanation: During the initialization process, the system only removes those tables that are declared in its current items.xml files. Old tables - orphaned data - stay intact.

answers.option: ant initialize -Dtenant=junit will initialize the junit tenant
ant updatesystem -DdryRun=true will create a sql script that is not executed
ant updatesystem -DconfigFile=path/to/my/config.properties is a valid command
answers.explanation: The config should be json file and it determines which essential data/project data will be executed.

questions.question: Statements

answers.option: Update (System) preserves the table name, to which a type was mapped, even if it was changed in items.xml
Update (System) preserves the column name, to which an attribute was mapped, even if it was changed in items.xml
Update (System) preserves the column type for an attribute, even if it was changed in items.xml
Update (System) will drop tables if they are removed from the items.xml
Update (System) can delete item data, including type instances and type system data (composed types etc.)
answers.explanation: Update does not delete any item data, including type instances and type system data (composed types etc.)

answers.option: Update (System) drops and recreate indices, if they are added or changed in items.xml
Update (System) does NOT change the attribute from mandatory to optional, even if it was changed in items.xml
answers.explanation: Update does NOT change the attribute from optional to mandatory, even if it was changed in items.xml

questions.question: It is possible to change an attribute from unique to non-unique in the items.xml

answers.explanation: But keep in mind: change from non-unique to unique is not performed (because existing data may conflict)

answers.option: A class with the following annotation will never be executed @SystemSetup(extension = "")
answers.explanation: The extension is missing.

answers.option: You can only have one method that is annotated with @SystemSetup in a class
answers.explanation: Multiple methods can be annotated.

answers.option: The annotation @SystemSetupParameterMethod can only be used within a clas that is annotated with @SystemSetup in a class

questions.question: Which are valid attributes for @SystemSetup?

answers.explanation: name is valid

questions.question: How can you track executed patches?

answers.option: You have to check the logfiles.
The history is tracked in the item UpdateSystemAudit

questions.question: The I18NService is an example of ...

answers.explanation: implement business use cases, such as cart handling or back order.
provide the underlying technical foundation, such as internationalization, import, export, and so on.
provide functionality required by the ServiceLayer, such as model handling and session handling.

questions.question: What is the meaning of the property: servicelayer.prefetch

answers.explanation: It is not recommended to set the loading mechanism to All to avoid loading too much data or, in case of circular dependencies, stack overflow exceptions.
This is the default setting. 'literal' behavior means pre-fetching only atomic attribute values and not pre-fetching reference attribute values.

questions.explanation:
When a Model is loaded, no Model values are loaded right away. The Model consists only of a blank Java object instance with no values set. All Model values are only loaded when any value of the Model is retrieved. This mechanism increases performance during Model initialization.

To change the loading mechanism, set the servicelayer.prefetch property in your local.properties file to all or literal.

questions.question:
ProductModel p1 = new ProductModel()

Will behave the same way as:

ProductModel p1 = modelService.create(ProductModel.class)

answers.explanation: If you create a Model by using its constructor, note that the Model is not attached to the Model context. You can attach it with modelService.attach(model). Also default values are not filled: modelService.initDefaults(model);

questions.question:
Consider to following code:

ProductModel exampleProduct = modelService.create(ProductModel.class);
exampleProduct.setCode("test");
ProductModel foundProduct = flexibleSearchService.getModelByExample(exampleProduct);

answers.option: It will find every product with the code 'test'
It might not find every product with the code 'test'

questions.explanation: If you create an example Model using the modelService.create() method, the Init Defaults Interceptor of this Model is called. As a consequence, default values of the Model are set and used as search parameters

questions.question: Which of the following interceptors is triggered before an item is saved?

answers.explanation: The Load Interceptor is called whenever a model is loaded from the database. You may want to use this interceptor if you want to change values of the model after load. An exception raised during execution prevents the model from being loaded.

The Init Defaults Interceptor is called when a model is filled with its default values. This happens either when it is created via the modelService.create method or when the modelService.initDefaults method is called.

The Prepare Interceptor is called before a model is saved to the database before it is validated by Validate interceptors, see below. Use this to add values to the model or modify existing ones before they are saved. An exception raised during execution prevents the model from being saved.

The Validate Interceptor is called before a model is saved to the database after is been prepared by the Prepare interceptors, above. You can use Validate Interceptors to validate values of the model and raise an InterceptorException if any values are not valid.
The Remove Interceptor is called before a model is removed from the database

questions.question: The Remove Interceptor is called after the items is removed.

answers.explanation: You should use the AfterSaveListener

questions.question: You can only replace existing interceptors by overriding them with the same bean ID.

answers.explanation: You can use the attribute replacedInterceptors to use another bean id

questions.question: A prepare interceptor can register items for removal.
questions.explanation:
Interceptors used to be limited to the scenario in which they were executed. For example, PrepareInterceptor could only register new models to be saved, and RemoveInterceptor could only register new models to be removed.

Currently the Prepare and the Remove interceptors can both register models and specify a PersistenceOperation to be performed with these models. PersistenceOperation is an enumeration with the following values

questions.question: You can disable a specific interceptor in an impex file

answers.explanation:
e.g. INSERT_UPDATE Currency[disable.interceptor.beans='validateCurrencyDataInterceptor'];isocode[unique=true];symbol;digits;

INSERT_UPDATE Currency[disable.UniqueAttributesValidator.for.types='Currency'];isocode[unique=true];symbol;digits;

questions.question: Statements.

answers.option: Events are always published on the same node.
answers.explanation: Events can either be published locally or across cluster nodes.

answers.option: To implement an event listener, extend from the abstract class AbstractEventListener
By default event publishing happens asynchronious
answers.explanation: Note that, by default, event publishing is synchronous on the same SAP Commerce Multichannel Suite instance.

answers.option: A custom event has to extend from ClusterAwareEvent
answers.explanation: It should extend from AbstractEvent. ClusterAwareEvent is an interface.

questions.question: How can you publish an event to a certain node?

answers.explanation: It should be ClusterAwareEvent. The TransactionAwareEvent: This is useful when you want to publish an events that notifies of model changes. Without a transaction aware the event would be published on each attribute change. But you probably only want it to be published once. You then implement a getId method that returns the item PK of the model.

answers.option: You have to call a specific method in the service EventService
You have to implement the method  public boolean publish(int sourceNodeId, int targetNodeId) in your custom Event class.
It is not yet possible (See 18.08 release)

questions.question: Which are valid bean scopes?

answers.explanation: The yrequest scope may be used for binding beans to the application context for a single request. This is similar to a standard Spring request scope but is used outside of a web application context.

questions.question: Which line should be added to the spring.xml so that a bean defined in the spring.xml can take advantage of @Autowired.

answers.explanation: This line is needed for beans declared using annotations.

questions.question:
Can you get the product code from the url with the following code:

@RequestMapping(value = "/stadiums/{stadiumName}")
And @PathVariable String stadiumName
Which filter should be used when you want to be able to change the tenant based on the url? (Still valid??)

answers.explanation: It takes care only of setting the tenant given by Spring configuration, without cooperation with the current session and switching possibility.

It assures that configured names of catalog versions are set as session catalog versions. Mentioned configuration is done through Spring property activeCatalogVersions. See also Configuring Existing Filters section for an example of bean with activeCatalogVersions property.
DynamicTenantSwitchingFilter: It uses the session for storing and fetching the tenant ID inside it. It offers also the the switching possibility, using given pattern as URL suffix.

questions.question: How can you access the the JaloSession?

answers.explanation: THIS NOT RECOMMENDED, but it gives you a better understanding of the place where the jalosession is stored.

questions.question: Where should you add a filter (that adds something on the session) so they will be triggered?

answers.option: In the web.xml with are reference to a Spring bean.
In a bean which uses PlatformFilterChain
answers.explanation: Every extension that has a web extension module needs to have its own definition of a custom filter chain based on the platformFilterChain Spring bean.

answers.option: In a bean which is named HybrisInitFilter

questions.explanation: Since Hybris 4.5, the HybrisInitFilter has been refactored. Now there is a set of new listers that easily can be overloaded.

questions.question: Which information is stored in a PK?

answers.explanation: The counter based PK is used as default, and the UUID PK is deprecated. That means that there is no information for the creation time included in the PK (be aware that getCreationTime() returns the counter for new PKs and the date for old PKs).

questions.question: What is ServiceLayer Direct?

answers.option: An extension with extra Service Layer functionality?
The new marketing name from SAP for the Jalo Layer

questions.question: What is the meaning of build.strict.compilation.mode=true

answers.option: All extensions are compiled using only their declared dependencies, not using one huge Platform-wide classpath.
It will always peform a clean before a build
The is a stricter compilation e.g. boolean a = new Boolean(true) will fail

questions.question: Which statements about the Hybris Cache are true?

answers.option: The hybris Cache is a part of the hybris persistence layer and enables to reduce the amount of database queries.
It improves the performance per single server node

questions.question: What will be stored in the Hybris Cache?

answers.option: Item instances, for example a Product
All item attributes, that is the result of getAllAttributes() or getAttribute(X) calls.

questions.question: When/how will data be invalidated from the Hybris Cache?

answers.option: A method can be called to invalidate the cache.
When using multiple cluster nodes, the other nodes can be notified via UDP multicast invalidation packets.
When the cache has reached the maximum size, it will invalidate certain items.
answers.explanation: The idea is correct, but it is not named invalidation but displacement.

questions.question:
Assume we executed the following query:
SELECT * FROM {product} WHERE {code} = "00001"
Hybris will cache our product item. What will happen when we would remove the product with code "00002"?

answers.option: Product 00001 will be removed from the cache ??????
Product 00002 will be removed from the cache ??????
When a product is removed, then its item data and the cached FlexibleSearch result for the above query is removed from the cache.???????????

questions.question: When happens displacement of the cache?

answers.option: When using multiple cluster nodes. One node can notify other nodes via TCP or UDP invalidation packets to displace their cache.
answers.explanation: This is cache invalidation.

answers.option: Inside a single VM, the cache invalidation is done by a method call.
The cache is full and removes an items to replace it with a new item.

questions.explanation: The cache framework detects that the cache entry is no longer valid and does not represent the correct database content. It is called invalidation.

questions.question: Statements about region cache.

answers.option: It has the possibility to use distributed cache.
It has the possibility to plug in other 3rd party cache frameworks, such as Coherence, Gigaspaces, Hazelcast, ...
The region cache always uses the eviction stategy: Least Recently Used (LRU)
answers.explanation: Least Recently Used (LRU), Least Frequently Used (LFU) and First In, First Out (FIFO) are supported

answers.option: The type system region has an unlimited size

questions.question: Which cache regions are standard configured?

answers.explanation: For storing entities of type system items
For storing entities of all types except type system ones
For storing all query results
For storing all media items

questions.question: How do you add a new cache region for caching custom POJOs?

answers.option: Update the local.properties to create a new region
answers.explanation: Of course you can set some configurations in the local.properties, but the region itself is created in the spring configuration.
e.g. class de.hybris.platform.regioncache.region.impl.EHCacheRegion

answers.option: It is not possible to use region cache for something else that Hybris Items.

questions.question: How can you manually clear the region cache?

answers.option:
With a groovy script: CacheController controller = [Lookup bean cacheController] ;
controller.clearCache();

With a groovy script: CacheService cacheService = [Lookup bean cacheService] ;
cacheService.clearCache();

This refers to TCP, which is not as fast

questions.question: Statements:

answers.option: local.properties has a higher priority than project.properties in the extensions.
Extension-specific project.properties files also are processed in a non-deterministic order. (Create extension dependencies.)
The default value: getString( String propertyName, String defaultValue ) has a lower priority than project.properties in the platform  direcoty.
It is not possible to overload properties in local.properties, since it has the highest priority.
answers.explanation: You can override them via the command line and on the fly in the HAC

questions.question: How can you access properties in spring?

answers.explanation: Since version 4.4, the hybris properties are provided in the global ApplicationContext of the hybris Multichannel Suite.

questions.explanation: The properties are provided by PropertyPlaceholderConfigurer with hybrisPropertiesConfigurer id, which gets the hybrisProperties bean injected. This bean fulfills the java.util.Properties class and holds all properties. You can use this bean in other scenarios too, especially if you want to use the hybris properties in your WebApplicationContext, having the global ApplicationContext as a parent.

questions.question: How can you configure cluster specific properties?

answers.option: A cluster node-specific property setting is prefixed by cluster.cluster_number
You can use a different config directory for each node to differentiate the properties.
you can configure the Apache Tomcat start-up settings via node-specific property values
you can specify node-specific build framework properties, such as a fictitious cluster.1.build.compiler=classic.
answers.explanation: Properties used at compile time can not be cluster specific.

answers.option: If no specific value for cluster.id is defined in local.properties file, the default value for the cluster.id is set to 15.

questions.question: How can you set properties:

answers.option: On the fly in the hac
Via command line ; java -Dfoo="some string" SomeClass

questions.question: How can you use local_myversion.properties in the config directory?
The server can not startup if the localextensions.xml is missing:
questions.explanation: The ${HYBRIS_CONFIG_DIR}/localextensions.xml file overrides the ${HYBRIS_BIN_DIR}/extensions.xml file. The two files are mutually exclusive, the localextensions.xml file is a "hard override" for the extensions.xml file: if a localextensions.xml file exists, the extensions.xml file is not even read in during a hybris Multichannel Suite build.

questions.question: What does autoload mean in the localextensions.xml? <extensions autoload="false">

answers.option: It doesn't exist, since you always have to add your extensions manually.
It will automatically load all the extensions in the ${HYBRIS_BIN_DIR}/platform/ext directory.
It will automatically load all the extensions that have have autoloadenabled="true" in the extensioninfo.xml

questions.question: Which files are generated when you create a new item?

answers.option: MyClassModel.java - a representation of the new Data Model in the service layer
MyClass(s)Resource.java and MyClass(s)DTO.java - support for CRUD via the hybris RESTful webservice
MyClass.java (persistance layer) not regenerated if it already exists

questions.question: What can you do to speed up development?

answers.option: Build you code using multiple cores: build.parallel=true

questions.question: What should you do when you want to start using/making unittest for the DAO-Classes?

answers.explanation: These are not needed.

answers.option: Enable the extensions you want to test for the tenant
It is not possible or not needed to initialize a tenant using ant.
answers.explanation: Another way of initializing the junit tenant is to run the ant yunitinit target.

answers.option: An integration test should extend the class TestCase.
answers.explanation: It should be ServicelayerTransactionalTest

questions.question: Which are good locations for unit tests?
Which statements are correct?

answers.option: The unit test class should be located in the same package as the class you want to test.
answers.explanation: By convention.

answers.option: The unit test class should have the extension 'Test'.
answers.explanation: By convention.

answers.option: The term mock refers to: Replacing an heavy-weight object on which an object under test usually depends
answers.explanation: Here is not the term mocking but stubbing explained. Mocking helps to verify if a conversation, for example a sequence of methods calls, between POJO1 and its dependent POJOs is as expected. It is usually done hand-in-hand with stubbing.

answers.option: By default all tests are IntegrationTests.
answers.explanation: As a fallback, all Tests that do not have one of the hybris annotations are treated as @IntegrationTests.

questions.question: How can you test transactional with isolation of the test.

answers.option: The test class has to extend ServiceLayerTransactionalTest.
answers.explanation: This class adds transaction-based isolation logic to your tests by registering the TransactionRunListener. However it is not the only way, it is also possible to use annotations.

answers.option: When the correct class is extended, a new transaction will be started just after the @Before annotation.
answers.explanation: Before the @Before method of your test is called, a new transaction is started.

answers.option: When the correct class is extended, a new transaction will be rolled back just after the @After annotation.
answers.explanation: After the @After method of your test is called, a transaction rollback is performed.

answers.option: You are required to use the @Transactional annotation.
answers.explanation: It is not required, you can also use 'extends ServiceLayerTransactionalTest'. The @Transactional annotation can be specified on a class or method level, so you can enable the transaction support for separate methods.

questions.explanation: Before the @Before method of your test is called, a new transaction is started. After the @After method of your test is called, a transaction rollback is performed.

questions.question: Which annotation should be used for tests that do not require a hybris environment in which to run, and are therefore fast.

answers.explanation: Tests that are to be executed inside an application server environment, like Apache Tomcat or WebSphere.
Typically well or self-documented Integration tests for inclusion in hybris Wiki and available to partners.

Tests that do not require a hybris environment in which to run, and are therefore fast. Unless your test needs the hybris environment, for example because of the persistence layer, then you should consider writing a unit test instead with mocked-out dependencies.
This annotation is available since hybris 4.4 version. Such a test can be configured to run under different circumstances, for example:6000 times in a row,with 1 mio items,under heavy load
This annotation is available since hybris 4.4 version. Some tests require external software, for example the CyberSource tests. These tests should not be executed during automated testing.

questions.question: Which of the following ant targets do not exist?
Which of the following statements are not true?

answers.option: Using ant it is possible to run all the unittests in a certain package(s)
answers.explanation: ant unittests -Dtestclasses.packages=de.hybris.platform.payment.*

answers.option: Using ant it is possible to exclude certain packages.
answers.explanation:
At least it is not possible from the command line.
<testclasses property="testlist" packages_negative="de.hybris.platform.*" />

answers.option: Using ant it is possible to run all the unittests in a certain extension(s).
answers.explanation: ant unittests -Dtestclasses.extensions=basecommerce,core

answers.option: Using ant it is possible to run all the unittests and manualtest at once.
answers.explanation: ant alltests -Dtestclasses.annotations=unittests,manualtests

answers.option: Using ant it is possible to run only the first 100 of 500 test.
answers.explanation: Assume there are 500 tests: ant alltests -Dtestclassses.split=1-5

questions.explanation: Like all other ant properties, these properties are set once and cannot be modified anymore. If you will call ant demotests -Dtestclasses.annotations=unittests, all UnitTests are executed.

questions.question: The buildcallbacks.xml of an extension has callbacks for that will be triggered at the following methods:

answers.explanation: (extension_name)_before_yunit

answers.option: Performed right after test execution, if tests succeed
answers.explanation: (extension_name)_after_yunit

answers.option: Performed right after test execution, if tests fails
Performed right before the test framework is initialized
answers.explanation: (extension_name)_before_yunitinit

answers.option: Performed right after the test framework has succesfully executed all the tests.
answers.explanation: Performed right after the test framework is initialized; (extension_name)_after_yunitinit
